questions.text: A 35year old man Rakesh is having difficulty in reading newspapers since last 6 months but his symptoms have worsened over the past 1 week. He has developed difficulty in chewing his favourite food (hamburger). He has no sensory complaints and his symptoms are improved significantly after rest. Which of the following is the main reason for his complaints?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in duration of absolute refractory period

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced Ca² + release at the axonal ending

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease in amplitude of Motor End Plate Potential

questions.correct_answer: D. Decrease in amplitude of Motor End Plate Potential

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. This arm is paralyzed when he awakens, but it tingles, and pain sensation in it is still intact. The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm-

options.label: A
options.text: A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than B fibers

options.label: B
options.text: A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

options.label: C
options.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers.

options.label: D
options.text: Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves.

questions.correct_answer: B. A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the mechanisms underlying skeletal muscle contraction. Which of the following temporal sequences is correct for excitation– contraction coupling in skeletal muscle?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased intracellular Ca² + ,actionpotential in the muscle membrane;cross-bridge formation

options.label: B
options.text: Action potential in the musclemembrane; depolarization of the T tubules; release of Ca² + from thesarcoplasmic reticulum (SR)

options.label: C
options.text: Action potential in the musclemembrane; splitting of adenosinetriphosphate (ATP); binding of Ca² + totroponin C

options.label: D
options.text: Release of Ca² + from the SR;depolarization of the T tubules; bindingof Ca² + to troponin C

questions.correct_answer: B. Action potential in the musclemembrane; depolarization of the T tubules; release of Ca² + from thesarcoplasmic reticulum (SR)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Excitation–contraction coupling in skeletal muscle involves a precise sequence of events:
  • • Action Potential Initiation: An action potential is generated in the muscle cell membrane (sarcolemma) following neural stimulation.
  • • T Tubule Depolarization: This action potential propagates along the sarcolemma and into the transverse tubules (T tubules), which are extensions of the sarcolemma that penetrate into the muscle fiber.
  • • Calcium Release: Depolarization of the T tubules activates voltage-sensitive dihydropyridine receptors, which are mechanically coupled to ryanodine receptors on the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This interaction leads to the opening of the ryanodine receptors and the release of Ca² + from the SR into the cytoplasm.
  • • Muscle Contraction: The increased intracellular Ca² + concentration binds to troponin C on the actin filaments, initiating the cross-bridge cycle and resulting in muscle contraction.
  • • This sequence ensures that the electrical signal (action potential) is effectively translated into a mechanical response (muscle contraction).
  • • Incorrect options:
  • • A. Increased intracellular Ca² + , action potential in the muscle membrane; cross-bridge formation: This sequence is incorrect because the action potential must precede the increase in intracellular Ca² + . The action potential triggers the release of Ca² + from the SR, which then leads to cross-bridge formation.
  • • C. Action potential in the muscle membrane; splitting of adenosine triphosphate (ATP); binding of Ca² + to troponin C: While ATP splitting is essential for the cross-bridge cycle, it is not a direct consequence of the action potential. The action potential leads to Ca² + release, which then facilitates ATP hydrolysis and cross-bridge formation.
  • • D. Release of Ca² + from the SR; depolarization of the T tubules; binding of Ca² + to troponin C: This sequence is incorrect because T tubule depolarization occurs before Ca² + release from the SR. The action potential first depolarizes the T tubules, which then triggers Ca² + release from the SR.

questions.text: 66-year-old woman with severemuscle weakness is hospitalized. The onlyabnormality in her laboratory values isan elevated serum K + concentration. Theelevated serum K + causes muscle weaknessbecause-

options.label: A
options.text: The resting membrane potential is hyperpolarized

options.label: C
options.text: K + channels are closed by depolarization

options.label: D
options.text: Na + channels are closed by depolarization

questions.correct_answer: D. Na + channels are closed by depolarization
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Elevated serum potassium (K + ) levels, a condition known as hyperkalemia, can lead to muscle weakness. In hyperkalemia, the increased extracellular K + concentration reduces the electrochemical gradient for K + across the muscle cell membrane, causing partial depolarization. This partial depolarization inactivates voltage-gated sodium (Na + ) channels, impairing action potential propagation and leading to muscle weakness.
  • • Incorrect options:
  • • A. The resting membrane potential is hyperpolarized: Hyperkalemia causes partial depolarization, not hyperpolarization, of the resting membrane potential.
  • • B. Na + equilibrium potential is hyperpolarized: The Na + equilibrium potential remains relatively constant; hyperkalemia affects the muscle cell membrane potential, not the Na + equilibrium potential.
  • • C. K + channels are closed by depolarization: Depolarization typically opens K + channels, allowing K + to exit the cell. In hyperkalemia, K + channels remain open, but the driving force for K + efflux is reduced due to the elevated extracellular K + concentration.

questions.text: The diagram below illustrates single isometric twitch contractions of two skeletal muscles, A and B, in response to a depolarizing stimulus. Which of the following best describes the muscle A?

options.label: A
options.text: Adapted for slow and sustained contraction

questions.correct_answer: D. Innervated by larger nerve fibers

questions.text: Choose from the diagram below the labelled line which best illustrates the change in RMP of a neuron when the extracellular K + concentration decreases three- fold and when sodium conductance increases maximally?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • When the extracellular K + concentration decreases three-fold, the resting membrane potential (RMP) becomes more negative (hyperpolarized). This occurs because the concentration gradient for K+ across the neuronal membrane increases, leading to a greater efflux of K + ions, which makes the inside of the neuron more negative. BRAINLY
  • • Simultaneously, when sodium conductance increases maximally, more Na + ions enter the neuron, causing depolarization. This influx of N + ions reduces the negative charge inside the neuron, making the membrane potential less negative (depolarized).
  • • The combined effect of these two changes is a shift in the RMP from a more negative value (hyperpolarized) to a less negative value (depolarized). In the provided diagram, this change is best represented by line E (indicating hyperpolarization) transitioning to line A (indicating depolarization).
  • • Incorrect options:
  • • A. Adapted for slow and sustained contraction: This option pertains to muscle physiology and does not relate to changes in neuronal resting membrane potential.
  • • B. Composed of smaller muscle fibers: This option also pertains to muscle physiology and is not relevant to neuronal RMP changes.
  • • D. Innervated by larger nerve fibers: While the size of nerve fibers can influence conduction velocity, it does not directly affect the RMP changes described in the question.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the properties of myosin-actin interactions in a sample of human muscle tissue. She has identified a drug that selectively inhibits phosphate release by the myosin head. If she gives this drug to a sample of human muscle tissue under physiologic conditions, which of the following steps in cross-bridge cycling will most likely be blocked?

options.label: B
options.text: Exposure of myosin-binding sites on actin

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her physician for her annual health check-up. She has no past medical history and says that she does not currently have any health concerns. On physical exam, she is found to have hyperactive patellar reflexes but says that she has had this finding since she was a child. She asks her physician why this might be the case. Her physician explains that there are certain cells that are responsible for detecting muscle stretch and responding to restore the length of the muscle. Which of the following is most likely a characteristic of these structures?

options.label: B
options.text: They are in series with extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers

options.label: C
options.text: They are in parallel with extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers

options.label: D
options.text: They are innervated by group Ib afferent neurons

questions.correct_answer: C. They are in parallel with extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers

questions.text: A new drug is developed that blocksthe transporter for H+ secretion in gastricparietal cells. Which of the followingtransport processes is being inhibited?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In gastric parietal cells, the secretion of hydrogen ions (H + ) into the stomach lumen is facilitated by the proton pump, also known as the H + /K + ATPase. This pump actively transports H + ions against their concentration gradient into the stomach, a process that requires energy in the form of ATP. Blocking this transporter inhibits the primary active transport mechanism responsible for acidifying the stomach.
  • • Incorrect options:
  • • A. Simple diffusion: This is a passive transport process where substances move down their concentration gradient without energy expenditure. The secretion of H + ions by the proton pump is an active process, not passive.
  • • B. Facilitated diffusion: This passive transport mechanism involves the movement of substances down their concentration gradient through a carrier protein, without energy input. The proton pump requires ATP, distinguishing it from facilitated diffusion.
  • • D. Cotransport: Also known as symport, cotransport involves the simultaneous transport of two substances in the same direction across a membrane, typically utilizing the gradient of one substance to drive the transport of another. The proton pump operates independently of other substances and does not utilize a cotransport mechanism.

questions.text: In a hospital error, a 50-year-old man is infused with large volumes of a solution that causes lysis of his red blood cells (RBCs).The solution was most likely

Solutions X and Y are separated bya membrane that is permeable to mannitol.Solution A is 10 mM mannitol, and solution B is5 mM mannitol. If the concentration of mannitol insolution A is doubled, the flux of mannitol acrossthe membrane will-

As a part of experimental protocol, 10g mannitol is injected into a volunteer to determine ECF volume. 10 % is excreted in the urine as determined by urinalysis. After waiting for sufficient time for equilibration, concentration of mannitol in ECF is found to be 90mg/100mL. What is the volume ofECF?

The body fluid volume changes in a 34 yearold patient are shown below in Darrow-Yannet diagram (solid line – normal, dotted line – patient). Which of the following is the cause of this patient’s condition?
Samit and Amit both weigh 80 kg. Samit drinks 2 L of distilled water, and Amit drinks 2 L of isotonic NaCl. As a result of these ingestions, Amit will have a-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • When Samit drinks 2 liters of distilled water, it is hypotonic relative to his body fluids. This ingestion leads to a decrease in plasma osmolarity, triggering the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). ADH promotes water reabsorption in the kidneys, resulting in the production of large volumes of dilute urine.
  • • In contrast, Amit consumes 2 liters of isotonic NaCl solution, which does not alter plasma osmolarity. Consequently, there is minimal ADH release, and the kidneys excrete a smaller volume of urine that is isotonic to plasma.
  • • Therefore, Samit's urine will be more dilute compared to Amit's, leading to a higher urine osmolarity in Amit's case.
  • • Incorrect options:
  • • A. Greater change in intracellular fluid (ICF) volume: Drinking distilled water can cause water to enter cells, leading to cell swelling. However, the question focuses on urine osmolarity, not ICF volume.
  • • B. Higher positive free-water clearance (CH 2 O): Free-water clearance is a measure of the kidney's ability to excrete water without solute. While Samit's ingestion of distilled water increases CH 2 O, the question asks for the effect on urine osmolarity, not CH 2 O.
  • • C. Greater change in plasma osmolarity: Drinking distilled water decreases plasma osmolarity, while isotonic NaCl ingestion has no effect. However, the question asks about urine osmolarity, not plasma osmolarity.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the excretion of a new drug Z by the kidney in order to understand the dynamics of this new substance. He discovers that this new drug Z has a clearance that is half that of inulin in a particular patient. This patient's filtration fraction is 20% and his para-amino-hippuric acid (PAH) dynamics are- Urinevolume:100mL/min UrinePAHconcentration:30mg/mL PlasmaPAHconcentration:5mg/mL Given these findings, what is the clearance of the novel toxin X?

A medical student is studying the fluid exchange in skeletal muscle capillaries in a laboratory animal. He determines that fluid is being filtered out of the capillaries with a net filtration pressure of 10mmHg. He obtains the following values – Capillary hydrostatic pressure is 45mmHg Capillary oncotic pressure is 25 mmHg Interstitial oncotic pressure is 10mmHg Which of the following is the interstitial hydrostatic pressure?
Researchers observe that there is deviation between actual threshold and predicted threshold of plasma glucose. This deviation is termed as splay. The reason for this splay is:

options.label: B
options.text: Transport maximum of all nephrons is same

options.label: C
options.text: It occurs due to kidney damage

questions.text: A healthy 33 year old man who exercises regularly has been consuming a high potassium diet rich in bananas before going to the gym for last 2 weeks. His urine potassium concentration is significantly higher in comparison to serum potassium concentration. Which of the following best describes the potassium levels in tubular fluid in comparison to the filtered load as tubular fluid flows along the nephron?

options.label: A
options.text: Bowman’s capsule- 100%, PCT- 35%, TAL- 10% and CD- 10%

options.label: B
options.text: Bowman’s capsule- 100%, PCT- 65%, TAL- 10% and CD- 0%

options.label: C
options.text: Bowman’s capsule- 100%, PCT- 65%, TAL- 10% and CD- 110%

options.label: D
options.text: Bowman’s capsule- 100%, PCT- 35%, TAL- 10% and CD- 110%

questions.correct_answer: D. Bowman’s capsule- 100%, PCT- 35%, TAL- 10% and CD- 110%

questions.text: Experimental studies are conducted to study renal tubular transport proteins. A new drug is developed that specifically and completely inhibits glucose transport in proximal renal tubules. Clearance of this drug will most likely be same as the substance –
Research experiments are being done to manipulate GFR and RPF. Which of the following will increase GFR but no change in FF?

A 55 year old male with central diabetes insipidus receives ADH injection. His urine output is significantly reduced after the injection. Which of the following substances will have the lowest clearance after the injection?

Scientists are studying the renal clearance of substance Z in experimental settings. At a constant GFR following values are obtained on substance Z titration curve. Substance z Filtered mg/min= 100 200 400 Substance Z Excreted mg/min= 100 200 400 Based on the data given above – renal handling of substance Z is most similar to which of the following?
Which curve describes the INULIN profile along the nephron?
Which curve describes the GLUCOSE profile along the nephron?

A 65-year-old man presents with acute onset abdominal pain radiating to his back, nausea, and vomiting. CT scan suggests a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. The pathogenesis of acute pancreatitis relates to inappropriate activation of trypsinogen to trypsin. Which of the following activates trypsin in normal digestion?

A researcher is studying the mechanism by which the gastrointestinal system coordinates the process of food digestion. Specifically, she is interested in how distension of the lower esophagus by a bolus of food changes responses in the downstream segments of the digestive system. She observes that there is a resulting relaxation and opening of the lower esophageal (cardiac) sphincter after the introduction of a food bolus. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in the process being observed here?

In an experimental model, a compound is centrally administered to rats. Following administration, the rats display increased desire for food and increased appetite. The administered compound is most likely similar to which of the following

Physiologists are studying the process of digestion in humans – it begins in the mouth by breaking food up into smaller particles through mastication and mixing it with saliva containing amylase. Food then enters the stomach, where gastric acid and pepsin initiate protein digestion. The resulting chyme is then expelled into the duodenum where pancreatic enzymes, such as lipase digest lipids. Resection of which of the following segments of the gastrointestinal tract would prevent the absorption of these digested lipids?

A 52-year-old woman presents to her family physician with 3 weeks of abdominal pain. She says that the pain is squeezing in character and gets worse after she eats fatty food. Furthermore, she has noticed that she has been experiencing episodes of nausea associated with abdominal pain in the last 5 days. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation and rebound tenderness in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. The hormone that is most likely responsible for the increased pain this patient experiences after eating fatty foods is most likely secreted by which of the following cells?

Scientists are studying the process of absorption of water in humans. Water is absorbed in the jejunum, ileum, and colon and excreted in the feces. Arrange these in order of the amount of water absorbed or excreted from greatest to smallest.

A researcher measures action potential propagation velocity in various regions of the heart in a 52-year-old female. Which of the following set of measurements corresponds to the velocities found in the Purkinje system, atrial muscle, ventricular muscle and A-V node respectively?

A 35-year-old man is running on the treadmill at his gym. His blood pressure prior to beginning his workout was 110/74. Which of the following changes in his cardiovascular system may be seen in this man now that he is exercising?

Preeti having history of coronary artery disease, starts running in the park. As she begins, her heart rate accelerates from a resting pulse of 65 bpm until it reaches a rate of 130 bpm, at which point she begins to feel a tightening in her chest. She stops running to rest and the tightening resolves. This has been happening to her consistently for the last 6 months. Which of the following is a true statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the heart rate increases the amount of time spent during each cardiac cycle

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the heart rate decreases the relative amount of time spent during diastole

options.label: C
options.text: Perfusion of the myocardium takes place primarily during systole.

options.label: D
options.text: Perfusion of the myocardium takes place equally throughout the cardiac cycle

questions.correct_answer: B. Increasing the heart rate decreases the relative amount of time spent during diastole

questions.text: You are evaluating a 72-year-old lady who presents to your office with fatigue and lower extremity edema. On exam you notice a distended, pulsating jugular vein. A jugular venous pressure tracing is shown in Figure A. In a healthy individual, the majority of the right ventricular filling occurs between which two points on the curve?

78-year-old male Ramesh, comes to the cardiologist for a health-check-up. He complains of increased lower extremity swelling, inability to climb the one flight of stairs in his home and waking up in the middle of the night 2-3 times gasping for breath. He has had to increase the number of pillows on which he sleeps at night. These symptoms started 9 months ago and have been progressing. The doctor starts him on a medication regimen, one of which changes his Starling curve from A to B as shown in the Figure. Which of the following medications is most consistent with this mechanism of action?

A 25-year-old labourer is brought to the emergency department from his construction job after he was hit in the head by a falling brick. He has no past medical history and is otherwise healthy. On presentation, he is found to be confused and somnolent with a notable bump over the temporal region of the skull. Trauma survey reveals no other injuries, and he does not appear to be actively bleeding at the time of presentation. A CT scan of the brain is obtained showing hyperdense material in the subarachnoid space and edematous brain tissue. Which of the following sets of blood pressure, heart rate, and respiratory rate may occur in response to the acute change in this patient's brain pathology?

An 80-year-old male presents with dyspnea, orthopnea, and a chest radiograph demonstrating pulmonary edema. A diagnosis of congestive heart failure is considered. The following clinical measurements are obtained: 100 bpm heart rate, 0.2 mL O2/mL systemic blood arterial oxygen content, 0.1 mL O2/mL pulmonary arterial oxygen content, and 500 mL O2/min oxygen consumption. Using the above information, which of the following values represents this patient's cardiac stroke volume?

A 66-year-old male with a history of myocardial infarction presents to your primary care office with complaints of dyspnea on exertion and swollen feet and ankles. On exam, you note an elevated JVP and 2+ pitting edema of bilateral lower extremities. What is the most likely explanation for this patient's lower extremity edema?
questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: The circuit shown below has an inflow pressure of 120 mm Hg and an outflow pressure of 40 mm Hg. Resistance in each of the four vessels is 4 mm Hg/mL/min. What is the total peripheral resistance of the circuit?

Cardiologists are studying membrane potential changes in an isolated cardiac muscle cell with ion movement across the cell membrane. Which of the following ion sequences corresponds to regions 1-2-3 on the graph respectively?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In cardiac muscle cells, the action potential progresses through distinct phases, each characterized by specific ion movements:
  • • Phase 0 (Depolarization): Rapid influx of sodium ions (Na + ) through voltage-gated sodium channels, leading to a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  • • Phase 1 (Initial Repolarization): Brief efflux of potassium ions (K + ) via transient outward potassium channels, causing a slight decrease in membrane potential.
  • • Phase 2 (Plateau Phase): Influx of calcium ions (Ca² + ) through L-type calcium channels, balanced by a continued K + efflux, maintaining a prolonged depolarized state.
  • • Phase 3 (Final Repolarization): Continued K + efflux through delayed rectifier potassium channels, leading to repolarization.
  • • Given these phases, the sequence of ion movements corresponding to regions 1-2-3 on the graph is:
  • • Region 1: Sodium (Na + )
  • • Region 2: Calcium (Ca² + )
  • • Region 3: Potassium (K + )
  • • Incorrect options:
  • • A. Potassium, sodium, calcium: This sequence does not align with the typical progression of the cardiac action potential phases.
  • • C. Calcium, sodium, chloride: Chloride ions play a minimal role in the cardiac action potential compared to Na + , K + , and Ca² + .
  • • D. Calcium, sodium, potassium: While Ca² + influx occurs during the plateau phase, the initial depolarization is primarily due to Na + influx.

questions.text: Shown below is the location of the high –pressure baroreceptors Physiologists study the effect of clamping the carotid sinus at ‘A’ and ‘B’ separately in 2 separate experiments. What will be most likely seen in A & B ?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased heart rate and increased blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Increased heart rate and decreased blood pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased heart rate and decreased blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased heart rate and increased blood pressure

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased heart rate and decreased blood pressure

questions.text: A 70 year old man with chronic hypertension is evaluated for chronic back pain. Her CT of thoracolumbar spine reveals a small left kidney. Angiography demonstrates atherosclerotic narrowing of the left renal artery. The right renal artery is intact. It is concluded that radius of the lumen has reduced by half? By what percentage flow has reduced in left renal artery in comparison to the right?
A 31-year-old female with a history of anxiety has a panic attack marked by dizziness, weakness, and blurred vision. Which of the following most likely accounts for the patient’s symptoms?
A man lost his right hand in a road accident, 5 years later he has episodes of severe pain in his missing limb (phantom limb pain). A detailed PET scan of his cerebral cortex will show –

options.label: A
options.text: Expansion of his right hand area in his right somatic sensory area (s1)

options.label: B
options.text: Expansion of his right hand area in his left somatic sensory area

options.label: C
options.text: Projection of the fibers from neighboring sensory areas into the right hand area of his left S1

options.label: D
options.text: Projection of the fibers from neighboring sensory areas into the right hand area of his right S1

questions.correct_answer: C. Projection of the fibers from neighboring sensory areas into the right hand area of his left S1

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents to his primary care physician because of a tremor that he has developed over the last several months. He says that the tremor is worst when he is resting but becomes better when he engages in movements such as picking up the remote for his TV. His wife also says that his movements have become slower over the last few months. Physical exam reveals increased resistance to passive motion of his extremities. Gait exam also shows trouble with starting movement and short, shuffling steps. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms involve the degeneration of a certain subset of neurons. When the substance released by these neurons interact with a G-alpha-s coupled receptor, which of the following effects occurs?

options.label: A
options.text: Inhibition of the globus pallidus externus

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulation of the globus pallidus externus

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of the globus pallidus internus

questions.correct_answer: D. Inhibition of the globus pallidus internus

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to dizziness, trouble with walking, and progressively worsening headache. These symptoms began approximately three hours prior to arriving to the hospital and were associated with nausea and two episodes of vomiting. Medical history is significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type II diabetes mellitus, which is managed with lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. His temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 174/106 mmHg, pulse is 106/min, and respirations are 24/min. On physical examination, the patient has right-sided dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing and right-sided dysrhythmia on rapid finger tapping. This patient's abnormal physical exam findings is best explained by decreased neuronal input into which of the following nuclei?

35-year-old woman comes to the neurologist with complaints of clumsiness. She feels like she is tripping over her feet more often, and she recently fell and sprained her wrist. Her medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension. She has been a strict vegan for over 10 years. She works as a receptionist in a super store. On examination, she appears well-nourished. She has diminished proprioception and vibration sense in both her feet. She has diminished Achilles reflexes bilaterally. Which of the following tracts are most likely damaged in this patient?

A intern is taking care of a patient with iron deficiency anemia as well as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. This patient presented to the hospital with shortness of breath and an oxygen saturation of 86% so he was placed on 1.5 L of inspired oxygen. His hemoglobin was found to be 10.5 g/dL. In order to better understand the pathophysiology underlying the care of this patient, the medical student decides to calculate the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the blood of this patient on presentation. If 1 gram of hemoglobin binds to 1.34 mL of oxygen, what is the amount of oxygen bound to 1 dL of this patient's blood?

A 68-year-old patient is recovering from acute lung injury following a diffuse pulmonary viral infection. The cell type responsible for the regeneration of the patient's alveolar epithelium is also functions in:

80- year- old man with a 40-pack-year history of smoking comes to his doctor's office complaining of shortness of breath. While sitting, the patient is leaning forward and breathing with his lips pursed. Auscultation of his lungs reveals a prolonged expiratory phase. Which of the following statements describes gas exchange in his lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: Gas exchange does not differ from that in a healthy individual

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen will fully equilibrate early along the length of the pulmonary capillary

options.label: C
options.text: The diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide is decreased

options.label: D
options.text: There is an increased surface area for gas exchange

questions.correct_answer: C. The diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide is decreased

questions.text: 68-year old man with sepsis has an increased peripheral metabolic rate and hypercapnia. With regard to carbon dioxide transport in this patient, which of the following physiologic processes is taking place?

options.label: A
options.text: Carbaminohemoglobin (carbon dioxide bound to hemoglobin) becomes the primary transport carrier of the additional carbon dioxide

options.label: B
options.text: More chloride enters the RBCs peripherally to compensate for increased carbonic anhydrase activity

options.label: C
options.text: The additional dissolved carbon dioxide becomes converted to bicarbonate, which binds to haemoglobin

options.label: D
options.text: Dissolved CO2becomes the primary transport carrier of the additional carbon dioxide

questions.correct_answer: B. More chloride enters the RBCs peripherally to compensate for increased carbonic anhydrase activity
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In sepsis, the body's metabolic rate increases, leading to elevated production of carbon dioxide (CO 2 ). To efficiently transport this excess CO 2 from tissues to the lungs for exhalation, the body utilizes the bicarbonate buffer system. Within red blood cells (RBCs), CO 2 is converted to bicarbonate (HCO 3 - ) through the action of the enzyme carbonic anhydrase. This conversion results in the production of HCO 3 - , which then diffuses out of the RBCs into the plasma. To maintain electrical neutrality, chloride ions enter the RBCs from the plasma, a process known as the "chloride shift." This mechanism ensures that the increased CO 2 produced during sepsis is effectively transported in the form of bicarbonate, with chloride ions compensating for the loss of bicarbonate from the RBCs.
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. Carbaminohemoglobin (carbon dioxide bound to hemoglobin) becomes the primary transport carrier of the additional carbon dioxide: While carbaminohemoglobin does play a role in CO 2 transport, it is not the primary mechanism for handling the increased CO 2 produced during sepsis. The bicarbonate buffer system, involving the chloride shift, is the main pathway for CO 2 transport under these conditions.
  • • C. The additional dissolved carbon dioxide becomes converted to bicarbonate, which binds to hemoglobin: Although CO 2 is converted to bicarbonate within RBCs, the bicarbonate primarily diffuses into the plasma rather than binding to hemoglobin. Hemoglobin does bind to CO 2 , but this is a separate process from the bicarbonate buffering system.
  • • D. Dissolved CO 2 becomes the primary transport carrier of the additional carbon dioxide: Dissolved CO 2 accounts for a small fraction of CO 2 transport. The majority is transported as bicarbonate ions in the plasma, with chloride ions entering RBCs to maintain charge balance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a 20-pack-year smoking history is referred for pulmonary function testing. On physical exam, he appears barrel-chested and mildly overweight, but breathes normally. Which of the following tests will most accurately measure his total lung capacity?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Whole body plethysmography is a pulmonary function test that accurately measures total lung capacity (TLC). This method involves the patient sitting in a sealed chamber and breathing through a mouthpiece. By applying Boyle's Law, which relates pressure and volume, the test calculates lung volumes based on pressure changes within the chamber. This technique is particularly useful for assessing lung volumes in patients with obstructive lung diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), where other methods might be less accurate.
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. Spirometry: Spirometry measures airflow and volumes during breathing but does not directly assess total lung capacity. It is useful for evaluating parameters like forced vital capacity (FVC) and forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV 1 ), which help in diagnosing obstructive and restrictive lung diseases.
  • • C. He-Dilution method: The helium dilution method estimates lung volumes by having the patient breathe in a known concentration of helium and measuring the dilution of the gas. While it can provide estimates of functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity, it may be less accurate in patients with obstructive lung diseases due to uneven ventilation.
  • • D. Open circuit N 2 washout method: This method involves the patient breathing 100% oxygen, which washes out nitrogen from the lungs. The concentration of nitrogen in exhaled air is measured to estimate lung volumes. Similar to the helium dilution method, it may be less accurate in patients with obstructive lung diseases.

questions.text: A 77-year-old male is brought in by paramedics after being found unconscious on the second floor of a burning building. On exam, his respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min with scattered wheezes. He has no evidence of any burns, but dark soot is caked around much of his face. Suspecting inhalational injury, you expect this man's oxygen-hemoglobin curve will be:

options.label: A
options.text: Unchanged, due to the fact that carbon monoxide (CO) is largely unbound and dissolved in plasma

options.label: B
options.text: Shifted right, due to strong competition between CO and O2 for binding

options.label: C
options.text: Shifted left, due to carbon monoxide binding

options.label: D
options.text: Shifted left, due to metabolic acidosis in tissues

questions.correct_answer: C. Shifted left, due to carbon monoxide binding

questions.text: A research scientist attempts to understand the influence of carbon dioxide content in blood on its oxygen binding. The scientist adds carbon dioxide to rabbit’s blood and measures the uptake of oxygen in the blood versus oxygen pressure in the peripheral tissue. He notes in one rabbit that with the addition of carbon dioxide with a pressure of 80 mmHg, the oxygen pressure in the peripheral tissue rose from 23 to 35 mmHg. How can this phenomenon be explained?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The Bohr effect describes how increased levels of carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) in the blood lead to a decreased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, facilitating oxygen release to tissues. When CO 2 levels rise, as they do during metabolic activity, the blood becomes more acidic (lower pH). This acidity causes hemoglobin to release oxygen more readily, ensuring that active tissues receive the oxygen they require. In the scenario described, the addition of CO 2 to the rabbit's blood results in a higher partial pressure of oxygen in the peripheral tissues, indicating enhanced oxygen delivery due to the Bohr effect.
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • B. Haldane effect: The Haldane effect refers to the property of hemoglobin where its oxygenation in the lungs promotes the release of CO 2 from the blood. While the Haldane effect is important for CO 2 transport, it does not explain the increased oxygen pressure in peripheral tissues observed in this experiment.
  • • C. Chloride shift: The chloride shift involves the exchange of bicarbonate and chloride ions across the red blood cell membrane to maintain electrical neutrality during CO 2 transport. While it plays a role in CO 2 transport, it does not directly explain the increased oxygen pressure in peripheral tissues observed in this experiment.
  • • D. Double Bohr effect: The term "double Bohr effect" is not a standard physiological concept. The Bohr effect itself adequately explains the observed phenomenon of increased oxygen pressure in peripheral tissues due to elevated CO 2 levels.

questions.text: A 55-year-old indian origin obese man presents to the emergency department with a fever and a cough productive of bloody sputum. He has also been waking up at night frequently, which he attributes to sweating while asleep. He is also proud of recently losing some weight but denies actively trying to do so. His housing has been transient with periods of homelessness. He is started on a course of therapy and leaves against medical advice before his physician is able to explain the medications. He returns two days later because he is concerned that his eyes are bleeding. The area of the lung most likely affected by this patient's condition has which of the following characteristics?

options.label: A
options.text: High perfusion, high ventilation, high V/Q ratio

options.label: B
options.text: Low perfusion, high ventilation, high V/Q ratio

options.label: C
options.text: Low perfusion, low ventilation, high V/Q ratio

options.label: D
options.text: Low perfusion, low ventilation, low V/Q ratio

questions.correct_answer: C. Low perfusion, low ventilation, high V/Q ratio

questions.text: Scientists working for a national endocrinology institute are investigating the specifics underlying glucose transport across skeletal muscle cell membranes. In one of the experiments they observe that transport of D- glucose is much faster than L- glucose across the muscle cell membranes. Which of the following processes is involved in transport of glucose across the skeletal muscle membrane?

A 45 year old Indian immigrant presents to the physician with significantly enlarged thyroid gland. Serum T3/T4 levels are decreased. Iodine deficiency is suspected. Which of the following is the function of thyroid peroxidase in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) plays a crucial role in the synthesis of thyroid hormones by catalyzing the oxidation of iodide ions (I - ) to reactive iodine (I - ) within the thyroid gland. This oxidation is essential for the subsequent iodination of tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin, leading to the formation of thyroid hormones such as thyroxine (T 4 ) and triiodothyronine (T 3 ). In the context of iodine deficiency, the activity of TPO becomes particularly significant, as the body attempts to compensate for the lack of dietary iodine by enhancing the utilization of available iodide for hormone synthesis.
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. Na + -Iodide uptake: The sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) is responsible for the active transport of iodide ions into the thyroid follicular cells, not for their oxidation. While NIS is essential for iodide uptake, it does not perform the oxidation reaction catalyzed by TPO.
  • • C. Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin is synthesized within the thyroid follicular cells and serves as the precursor protein for thyroid hormone production. Its synthesis is a separate process from the oxidation of iodide, which occurs in the follicular lumen and is catalyzed by TPO.
  • • D. Iodo-tyrosine deiodination: Deiodination of iodotyrosine residues on thyroglobulin is a process that occurs after the formation of thyroid hormones, primarily in peripheral tissues. This process is not directly related to the initial oxidation of iodide by TPO within the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to her gynaecologist’s clinic for a postpartum check-up. She gave birth to a 37-week-old girl via a caesarean section 4 weeks ago and has been exclusively breastfeeding her daughter. The hormone most responsible for promoting milk let-down during lactation in this new mother would lead to the greatest change in the level of which of the following factors?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The hormone most responsible for promoting milk let-down during lactation is oxytocin. Oxytocin binds to receptors on the myoepithelial cells surrounding the alveoli in the mammary glands, initiating a signaling cascade that leads to milk ejection. This process involves the activation of the phosphatidylinositol (PI) pathway, which generates inositol trisphosphate (IP 3 ) as a second messenger. IP 3 stimulates the release of calcium ions from intracellular stores, leading to the contraction of myoepithelial cells and facilitating milk let-down.
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. cAMP: While cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) is a second messenger in various signaling pathways, it is not the primary mediator in the oxytocin-induced milk let-down reflex.
  • • B. cGMP: Cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) also serves as a second messenger in some physiological processes but is not involved in the oxytocin-mediated milk ejection mechanism.
  • • D. Tyrosine kinase pathway: The tyrosine kinase pathway involves receptors that phosphorylate tyrosine residues and is not the primary signaling mechanism for oxytocin's action in milk let-down.

questions.text: 25-year-old female presents complaining of recent weight loss and weakness. She reports that she feels dizzy and lightheaded every morning when she gets out of bed, and often at work whenever she rises up from her office desk. Physical exam reveals several areas of her skin including her elbows and knees are more pigmented than other areas. Which of the following would be consistent with the patient's disease?

24-year-old patient comes to the physician’s clinic with complaints of headaches and difficulty seeing out of the corner of her eye. She gave birth to her son 10 months ago. Further visual testing reveals the patient has bitemporal hemianopsia. The patient undergoes brain MRI which shows an anterior pituitary mass, likely adenoma. The patient has her blood tested to see if the adenoma is secreting extra hormone. The patient is found to have a slight excess of a hormone that uptakes a basophilic stain. Which of the following is most likely to be the hormone detected in her blood?

A 46-year-old male complains of carpopedal spasms, peri-oral numbness, and paresthesias of the hands and feet. His wife also mentions that he had a seizure not too long ago. His past surgical history is significant for total thyroidectomy due to papillary thyroid carcinoma. They then realized all of the symptoms occurred after the surgery. Which of the following would be present in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Trousseau sign, QT prolongation, increased PTH, decreased serum calcium, decreased serum phosphate

options.label: B
options.text: Trousseau sign, QT prolongation, decreased PTH, increased serum calcium, decreased serum phosphate

options.label: C
options.text: Trousseau sign, QT prolongation, decreased PTH, decreased serum calcium, increased serum phosphate

options.label: D
options.text: Trousseau sign, QT shortening, decreased PTH, decreased serum calcium, increased serum phosphate

questions.correct_answer: C. Trousseau sign, QT prolongation, decreased PTH, decreased serum calcium, increased serum phosphate

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident a 28-year-old man becomes paraplegic because of injury to his spinal cord at T1. patient complains of chronic constipation, but he wants to be as independent as possible in its treatment. His physician advises him to distend the rectum digitally on a regular schedule to initiate the defecation reflex. Rectal distention causes which of the following in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Contraction of the internal anal sphincter

questions.text: A 28 year old bodybuilder goes to the gym on his way home from work. He runs on the treadmill for 30 minutes, lifts weights for 20 minutes, and does push-ups and sit-ups for 10 minutes. Which of the following is quantitatively the most important method for transporting the CO 2 in the blood that is produced by his muscles?

A 17-year-old patient suffering from type 1 diabetes is noncompliant with his required insulin therapy and develops hyperglycemia after eating chocolate. The release of which of the following intestinal hormones would most likely be stimulated?

A 72-year-old woman has been diagnosed with Zollinger- Ellison syndrome, she undergoes a gastrectomy for the same following which her physician informs her that she will need to take intramuscular vitamin B12 shots for the rest of her life. Absence of which of the following cell types is responsible for this vitamin replacement requirement?

A 51-year-old woman presents to the hospital OPD complaining of fatigue. There is no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea, but physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a plasma sodium level of 129 mEq/L and a potassium level of 5.5 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hyponatremia?

A researcher is studying pancreatic function on a patient. The student is specifically trying to understand the insulin secretion pattern in the pancreatic cells. The researcher is presented with a list of substances that affect insulin secretion. He clicks on a substance and finds that it directly inhibits the patient’s insulin secretion. This response was most likely caused by which of the following substances?

In a tissue capillary, the interstitial hydrostatic pressure is 2 mm Hg, the capillary hydrostatic pressure is 25 mm Hg, and the interstitial oncotic pressure is 7 mm Hg. If the net driving force across the capillary wall is 3 mm Hg favoring filtration, what is the capillary oncotic pressure?
